body.p: How can anthropologists look at a skeleton and judge the age of the individual?

multiple_choice.choice: younger individuals having weak, brittle bones
presence of epiphyseal line rather than epiphyseal plate
bone facial features changing during puberty
loss of bone in the mandible

response.feedback: Correct. In adults the hyaline cartilage of the epiphyseal plate has been replaced with bone and is known as the epiphyseal line.
Incorrect. Often the mandible (jaw) of ancient individuals was worn out over a lifetime of chewing, but this wear is greatly impacted by the environment (the available food sources).
Incorrect. Many adults of all sizes have strong bones until very late in life. Children with poor nutrition can have brittle bones (such as in the disorder called "rickets").
Incorrect. Our faces do sometimes change as they mature, but not greatly.

part.hint: Think about which characteristics of bones are only associated with children.
These answers may all seem correct, but keep in mind that many factors can be influenced by genetic or environmental variation.
